'(AFPRT)
A +3 arrow particularly deadly to a certain type of creature. There is always some mark
column21:
to denote the type of target the arrow will instantly slay on a successful attack. A chart is included for random determination but the GM is advised to modify the chart to fit his or her unique milieu. One should note the type can be as general as “humanoid” or as specific as “hobgoblin.”

'(F)
Usually functions as a +2 hammer. In the hands of a dwarfish fighter who knows the command word
column23: this weapon is a full +3 warhammer. The hammer of the dwarfs retains its attack bonus when hurled as a missile weapon
column24: doing double damage if it hits and boomeranging back to its owner. If thrown at a giant opponent (including ogres
column26: and ettin) the hammer will cause triple damage if it hits.'

column20:
'(CFPR)
A +1 mace with special powers vs evil creatures and the undead. The mace has a neutral good alignment and does 5d4 points of bonus damage to any evil target it strikes. Against the undead
column22: the holy mace reveals its true power. When the mace strikes a demon
column25: a turn undead roll is made on the Turning Undead table as the wielder were a 12th level cleric. If the creature fails its roll it is immediately blasted out of existence by the holy power of the mace. Some creatures (example: skeletons
column27: and ghouls) are automatically destroyed. Stronger undead creatures which have a numerical result instead of a “T” or “D” on the matrix get that number as a saving throw vs disruption. Even if the undead target makes its saving throw or is immune to disruption
column28: the mace will still deal double the damage plus double the damage bonus.'

column20:
'(CFPR)
A +1 mace with special powers vs evil creatures and the undead. The mace has a neutral good alignment and does 5d4 points of bonus damage to any evil target it strikes. Against the undead

column27: and ghouls) are automatically destroyed. Stronger undead creatures which have a numerical result instead of a “T” or “D” on the matrix get that number as a saving throw vs disruption. Even if the undead target makes its saving throw or is immune to disruption
column28: the mace will still deal double the damage plus double the damage bonus.'

column18:
'(AFPRT)
A shorter than normal trident with a 6 ft haft
column19: usable as a melee or missile weapon but too short in this mode to be set against a charge. When the command word is spoken
column20: the trident lengthens into a full pole arm and can be set against a charge as a normal pole arm. In either mode
column21: the weapon is +3 to hit and damage.'

column20: but is figured as a +1 weapon in terms of which creatures it can affect.'
the bleeding sword is a +1 blade with a terrible power. Any damage caused by this weapon is progressive for up to 10 melee rounds on a 1 for 1 basis. An attack causing 5 points of damage
column22: will cause an additional 5 points of damage the next combat round and each following round; up to 50 damage points total. Hit point damage can be halted by the victim leaving combat and binding his or her wounds. All hits from this blade do damage the same way. Wounds caused by this magic sword can only be healed with rest and time; no curative magic of any type will be effective. Even creatures capable of regenerating cannot heal themselves thus
column23: whether this a natural ability (trolls) or magical ability (ring of regeneration).'

column19:
'(AFPRT)
An unusual weapon. During the first round the dancing sword is used in combat it performs as a +1 blade. Each subsequent round the sword adds an additional +1 bonus up to the maximum of +4 in the fourth round. In round 5 the process begins again
column20:
and at this point the blade can “dance”.

A dancing sword can then be loosed from the wielder’s hand to fight on its own for 4 rounds
column21: up to 30 ft away. The dancing sword will fight as if still being held by the owner and gains the successive bonuses to its attack and damage each round. When the dancing sword cycles from +4 back to +1 it will return to its owner’s hand
column22:
where it must be wielded for 4 rounds before being released to dance again.

If the owner declines to grasp the sword when it returns to him or her
column23: or if he or she moves more than 30 ft away from the dancing sword
column24: the weapon will fall inanimate to the ground. The sword cannot be physically attacked by its opponent while dancing
column25: though it is subject to magical attacks and effects (examples: fireball
column26: transmute metal to wood). While the sword is dancing
column27: the wielder can perform any other action he or she wishes

column20: but the wielder of this sword has the option each round of adding all or part of the bonus to his or her AC. Thus
column21: a fighter could increase his or her current AC of 2 (plate mail with shield) to AC 0 by deducting 2 points from the sword’s +4 bonus and making the defender> +2 to hit for that round. '

column20: +4 vs all dragons and against one specific type of dragon (determined randomly) deals triple damage. If one of these swords should be determined to be intelligent (see below)
column21: it will in no way allow the player to slay a dragon of the same alignment. A chart is included to assist the GM with selecting a dragon type for triple damage. Since a campaign may include other types of dragons
column22:
the GM may wish to modify this list.

'(AFPRT)
The blade of this weapon bursts into flame when its command word is spoken
column20: giving illumination as a torch. The sword does not otherwise glow as most other magic swords do. The flame tongue’s fiery blade can easily ignite paper
column24:
or dry wood.
The sword is normally +1
column25: but gives a +2 as a trollbane does
column26: a +3 bonus against creatures that are inflammable
column27: bird-like or have a special attack involving cold
column28: and a +4 against undead. These bonuses do not stack; only the highest bonus should be counted. (Thus

column20: granting a +6 bonus against any creature using fire as its attack (e.g. red dragons) or dwelling in fire such as fire elementals. This weapon grants special defence against fire; treat the wielder as if he or she were wearing a ring of fire resistance. The cold based magic of the blade also has a 50% chance of extinguishing fire for a 10 ft radius
column21: including magical fires such as a wall of fire but not fire based attacks such as hell hound breath attacks or fireballs. Note: this blade does not shed light when drawn unless the ambient temperature is below freezing.'

column19:
'(AFPRT)
This sword will be +2 when fighting most foes. Against giant-like humanoids such as ettin or ogres
column20: the giant slayer functions as a +3 blade. Against true giants such as hill giants or storm giants
column21: the sword also does double damage.'
